title: How to Troubleshoot Sound Issues on Your Windows Device

steps.title: Make sure the volume isn't muted.
steps.content: Make sure the volume isn't muted. Locate the speaker icon to the left of the system clock, which is usually at the bottom-right corner of the screen. If you see an X beside it, your PC's volume is muted. If your keyboard has volume buttons, press the Mute button (the speaker with an Xâ€”usually F1) to unmute the speaker, or just press the Volume Up button (usually F3) several times until the volume increases. You can also increase the volume by clicking the speaker icon and then dragging the corresponding slider up (Windows 10) or to the right (Windows 11).

steps.title: Right-click the volume icon and select Open Volume Mixer.
steps.content: Right-click the volume icon and select Open Volume Mixer . You'll find the speaker icon in the system tray at the bottom-right corner of the screen on both Windows 10 and Windows 11. The volume mixer allows you adjust the volume for individual apps.

steps.title: Use the sliders to adjust the volume levels for apps.
steps.content: Use the sliders to adjust the volume levels for apps. If the volume is turned down for the app that's trying to play audio, raising the volume should resolve the issue. If you're using Windows 11, you'll also see a section in the Volume Mixer for "Output device." If you don't see the device you're trying to listen to selected here, click the menu and select it now.

steps.title: Check the volume on your physical speaker.
steps.content: Check the volume on your physical speaker. If you're using an external speaker or headset that has its own volume controls, make sure the volume is turned up on the speaker itself.

steps.title: Check the connection to your speaker or headphones.
steps.content: Check the connection to your speaker or headphones . If you can't hear audio from your speakers or headphones, make sure you've plugged them into the correct port (not the microphone port!) and that the connections are securely in place. If the speaker requires a power source, such as being plugged into a wall or USB port, double-check to make sure that it's powered on. If your external speaker is a part of a multi-speaker system, double-check that all components are turned on and properly connected. Using a Bluetooth speaker ? Try disconnecting from it, placing it back into pairing mode, and then reconnecting.

steps.title: Make sure the audio output is correct.
steps.content: Make sure the audio output is correct. Many audio issues are caused by Windows playing audio through the wrong device. For example, Windows may be trying to play audio through an external speaker instead of your built-in speakers. Click the volume icon on the taskbar once with the left mouse button, and then click the audio device you want to listen through. If you don't see a Bluetooth speaker or device you're trying to listen through as an option, you may need to reconnect to it .

steps.title: Restart your computer.
steps.content: Restart your computer. Before proceeding to another method, try to reset your audio by restarting your computer. If your computer loads up with the sound is fixed, you needn't continue.

steps.title: Open the Audio Troubleshooter.
steps.content: Open the Audio Troubleshooter. The Audio Troubleshooter can fix just about any problem that's related to sound on your computer. Here's how to open it on both Windows 10 and Windows 11: Press Windows key + S to activate the search bar. Type audio troubleshooter . Click Find and fix problems with playing sound . [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Next on the troubleshooter.
steps.content: Click Next on the troubleshooter. Now a list of audio devices will appear.

steps.title: Select a device and click Next.
steps.content: Select a device and click Next . Once you click Next , the troubleshooter will check for issues with that device.

steps.title: Repair any issues found by the troubleshooter.
steps.content: Repair any issues found by the troubleshooter. The troubleshooter will prompt you to allow certain changes to be made, such as re-enabling an audio device or turning off sound enhancements. Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the troubleshooter.

steps.title: Open the Control Panel.
steps.content: Open the Control Panel . If you have any of Windows' sound enhancements applied to your speaker or headphones, it may be malfunctioning and causing no sound. Start by opening the Control Panel: Press Windows key + S to activate the search bar. Type control panel . Click Control Panel in the search results.

steps.title: Click Hardware and Sound.
steps.content: Click Hardware and Sound . If you don't see this option, just move to the next step.

steps.title: Click Sound.
steps.content: Click Sound . This opens the Sound control panel, where you'll see a list of speakers, headphones, and other playback devices.

steps.title: Make sure the correct speaker is set as the default.
steps.content: Make sure the correct speaker is set as the default. The playback device with a green checkmark is the one set as your default speaker. If you see the wrong speaker selected, you can choose a different speaker as the default by clicking that speaker and selecting Set Default . [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click the default speaker(s) and select Properties.
steps.content: Click the default speaker(s) and select Properties . This opens settings specific to this device.

steps.title: Click the Enhancements tab.
steps.content: Click the Enhancements tab. If you don't see this tab, you may have tabs for specific enhancements, such as Dolby Audio .

steps.title: Disable available enhancements.
steps.content: Disable available enhancements. If you see the option to Disable all enhancements, select that option now. Otherwise, disable any enhancements you see individual and retest the sound. Click Preview to test the sound. If this corrected the issue, click OK to save your settings. If disabling enhancements doesn't bring back sound, re-enable them continue with this method.

steps.title: Click the Advanced tab.
steps.content: Click the Advanced tab. It's at the top of the window.

steps.title: Select a different frequency from the "Default Format" drop-down menu.
steps.content: Select a different frequency from the "Default Format" drop-down menu. If the menu initially had "24 bit" as the option, select a 16-bit option (or vice versa).

steps.title: Click Test.
steps.content: Click Test . This option is on the right side of the window. Clicking it will cause your speakers to play a tune if they're working. Repeat the test with each frequency. If you find a frequency that produces audio, you've resolved your computer's audio issues. Click OK to close the window when you're finished.

steps.title: Open your Windows Services.
steps.content: Open your Windows Services . If the services related to audio on your PC have stopped or are malfunctioning, you may be able to resolve sound issues by restarting them. To open your services: Press Windows key + S to activate the search bar. Type services . Click Services in the search results.

steps.title: Right-click "Windows Audio" and select Restart.
steps.content: Right-click "Windows Audio" and select Restart . This restarts the primary audio service.

steps.title: Right-click "Windows Audio Endpoint Builder" and click Restart.
steps.content: Right-click "Windows Audio Endpoint Builder" and click Restart . This restarts another service that's important for audio.

steps.title: Right-click "Remote Procedure Call (RPC) and click Restart.
steps.content: Right-click "Remote Procedure Call (RPC) and click Restart . Once you've restarted all of these services, you can close the Services window.

steps.title: Test your sound again.
steps.content: Test your sound again. If your sound still isn't working, try another method.

steps.title: Open the Device Manager.
steps.content: Open the Device Manager. If your audio drivers are corrupt or out of date, it could prevent sound from playing through your speakers or headphones. To open Device Manager: Press Windows key + S to open the search bar. Type device manager . Click Device Manager in the search results.

steps.title: Scroll down and click the arrow next to Sound, video, and game controllers.
steps.content: Scroll down and click the arrow next to Sound, video, and game controllers . This displays a list of all audio drivers.

steps.title: Right-click your sound card and select Properties.
steps.content: Right-click your sound card and select Properties . Your sound card might be called something like "Realtek High Definition Audio."

steps.title: Click the Driver tab.
steps.content: Click the Driver tab. It's at the top of the dialog window.

steps.title: Click Update driver.
steps.content: Click Update driver .

steps.title: Click Search automatically for updated driver.
steps.content: Click Search automatically for updated driver . This tells Windows to search the internet and the files on your computer for more up-to-date sound drivers .

steps.title: Install the new drivers if prompted.
steps.content: Install the new drivers if prompted. You may have to confirm this decision by clicking Yes or Install , though new drivers will typically download on their own. If Windows doesn't find a new sound driver, check your computer manufacturer's website for the most recent drivers. If you're still not able to update the audio driver, you'll want to remove it. Click Uninstall Device , check the box next to "Delete the driver software for this device," and then click Uninstall .

steps.title: Restart your computer and test the sound.
steps.content: Restart your computer and test the sound. Once the drivers are finished installing, you'll want to restart your computer to finish implementing the changes. If your drivers were the reason your computer's sound wasn't working, you should now have sound.

steps.title: Open the Device Manager.
steps.content: Open the Device Manager. Some Windows PCs have a driver called IDT High Definition Audio CODEC in the Device Manager. This CODEC can cause problems with the audio system if the driver isn't configured properly. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source To open Device Manager: Press Windows key + S to open the search bar. Type device manager . Click Device Manager in the search results.

steps.title: Scroll down and click the arrow next to Sound, video, and game controllers.
steps.content: Scroll down and click the arrow next to Sound, video, and game controllers . This displays a list of all audio drivers.

steps.title: Right-click "IDT High Definition Audio CODEC" and select Update Driver.
steps.content: Right-click "IDT High Definition Audio CODEC" and select Update Driver . If you don't see this item in Device Manager, this method won't work.

steps.title: Click Browse my computer for driver software.
steps.content: Click Browse my computer for driver software . Additional options will appear.

steps.title: Click Let me pick from a list of device drivers on my computer.
steps.content: Click Let me pick from a list of device drivers on my computer . A list of pre-installed drivers will appear.

steps.title: Select "High Definition Audio Device" and click Next.
steps.content: Select "High Definition Audio Device" and click Next . This replaces the driver with a more general driver designed to work on a wider variety of PCs. Restart your PC after adding the driver and test your sound.
